txt.en: 'No! No. I beg you, do not.'
Instance: The Forbidden Pool
'He knows nothing of the ways of Men, and I doubt he knows you are here.'
'But also, it is likely that he has been drawn here by some mastering desire. The lure is stronger than his caution...'
'Yes. He bore it himself for many years. It is precious to him.'
'Because he is hungry, and wretched...'
'And because Mithrandir himself would have forbade it, as he forbade the Elves to harm him.'
'I do not understand why, or how, but this creature is bound to my errand in some unforeseen way... he is our guide.'
'Let me go down to him, as quietly as I can. You may shoot me if I fail.'
'...But why must we trust Master? Where is the other hobbit, the rude and cross one?'
'What is it? Not a hobbit! Something is there!'
'Nasssty, wicked, tricksy Master!'
'Shall we shoot, Master Baggins?'
'So you know what this thing is, I take it? Come, tell me why we should spare it.'
'In all of our long talks together, you have not spoken of the gangrel-companion, and I have let it be.'
'He has now done worse than trespass and poach in Ithilien! He has dared to come to the very door of Henneth Annûn.'
'We are discovered. My bow is at the ready, Captain.'
'Why does he come beneath our very window, if it means his life is forfeit?'
'I have him in my sight, Captain. Do I shoot? It is death by law to come unbidden to the pool.'
'Can he then know of your burden?'
'Go quickly, and be careful. Unseen archers are poised to shoot at any sign of trouble.'
'Not yet, Anborn. This is a more difficult matter than it seems.'
'Hold still, now, or we'll stick you full of sharp arrows!'
'Why should we spare him?'
'Very well. Anborn, lead Frodo to the bank.'
'Up ahead. Be good, Sméagol, and follow me this way.'
'If you do not come, the Precious will be very angry. In front now!'
'Please be gentle with him! Sméagol! Trust Master, Sméagol...'
